Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Multi-Scale Analysis of Catalytically Grown Carbon Nanofibers and Bulk Components

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Nanomaterials are advanced materials which have at least one dimension below 100 nanometers, or about one one-thousandth the width of a human hair. The most widely studied nanomaterials are based on carbon, as these materials have the potential to transform society by allowing stronger, lighter structures, more efficient computing and advanced medical applications. The drawback is that they often require specialized processing which is difficult to scale up economically. A critical transition must be made to convert their theoretical potential into real-world performance. This award enables fundamental research into a new process which efficiently produces bulk components made entirely of carbon nanofibers. This highly versatile material has the potential to broadly impact society and the economy by enabling applications in transportation, energy, environmental and medical disciplines. This research will use multi-scale analysis to understand how the fibers form (nanoscale), how they interact (microscale) and how they behave collectively as a bulk component (macroscale). Such diverse topics require a multi-disciplinary approach to holistically unite nanoscale materials science, chemical engineering and advanced manufacturing. The project will engage these diverse groups at the professional and educational levels and demonstrate the importance of preparing science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) students for a multi-disciplinary workplace.

The direct synthesis of bulk components comprised entirely of carbon nanofibers creates a stand-alone embodiment for the application of nanoscale carbon. Carbon nanofibers are formed during the decomposition of a carbon-containing gas over a suitable catalyst. The catalyst is placed within a constrained environment (a mold), which the nanofibers fill during growth. After sufficient growth, the fibers form a highly entangled, bulk component which is mechanically robust. There are many factors which can alter the properties of the three-dimensional fiber collection, and the objective of this research is to understand the governing factors from fiber formation at the catalyst to fiber interaction in the bulk. An important understanding of fiber growth using low-cost, bulk catalysts will be attained by uniquely controlling composition and microstructure through mechanical alloying. Foundational metrics will be established for this brand-new process in the areas of kinetics, morphology and long-range response of fiber growth to constraint. The bulk properties will also be identified as a function of those structural characteristics. This multi-scale approach is critical to accurately couple processing, properties and performance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite being studied for decades, there has been limited commercialization of carbon nanofibers (CNFs) and no known success in producing components or devices directly from them. This project has demonstrated two transformative concepts in the production and use of CNFs: (1) catalyst can be prepared using mechanical alloying, and (2) free-standing bulk components can be directly synthesized. Catalyst preparation has been simplified dramatically, such that grams per minute of highly active catalyst can be produced using laboratory-scale techniques with unique control over microstructure. The investigation of microstructural control is an important advancement, because the efficiency of the catalytic carbon deposition has been correlated with reduced grain size and increased defect density achieved by severe plastic deformation, as induced with ball milling of metallic powders. The development of free-standing components is a completely unique accomplishment, as these components can be shaped by formation in a mold and are in excess of 99% carbon, even without removing the catalyst chemically. These materials are structurally robust, easily handled, and able to withstand repeated high-strain loading. When considered together, these two factors are a synergistic pairing, such that a catalyst can be produced efficiently, and components can be produced simply and accurately. The basic understanding of deposition mechanisms and microstructural control, and the development and regulation of nanofibrous growth over length scales covering multiple orders of magnitudes, would not have been possible without this project funding. These advancements, and the practical demonstration of their utility, are expected to initiate further interest and development in these areas.

                In addition to the basic science and the broad range of applications served by these findings, this project has had an exceptional impact on student development, such that future scientists and engineers have been afforded opportunities they would not have otherwise had. This work was performed at an undergraduate institution with limited research resources. This award was the PI?s first, and the only research project on campus in materials engineering. Because of the uniqueness, the project necessitated new equipment and facilities, which in turn, provided new training opportunities for students. In this way, the advancement of current students was achieved as well as providing a foundation for future growth. A diverse group of undergraduate students was involved in every aspect of the work, from setting up equipment, to performing experiments and characterization, to writing and publishing journal articles and presenting nationally at numerous conferences. This project also initiated cross-campus collaborations between departments, with the PI overseeing students from Applied Engineering, Chemistry, and Physics. Through this project, the PI has also established a network of external facilities to support the work and provide students with opportunities to visit these locations and gain experience with equipment not available in-house. In addition to the students directly involved in the work, aspects of it have been incorporated in general curriculum, such that all students get some exposure to the topics. This project and ongoing efforts have also led to the creation of a dedicated nanomaterials research lab. This new space will be used to serve the scientific community and inspire students for years to come.


Last Modified: 10/24/2018
Modified by: Mark Atwater

The investigation of microstructural control is an important advancement, because the efficiency of the catalytic carbon deposition has been correlated with reduced grain size and increased defect density achieved by severe plastic deformation, as induced with ball milling of metallic powders. The development of free-standing components is a completely unique accomplishment, as these components can be shaped by formation in a mold and are in excess of 99% carbon, even without removing the catalyst chemically. These materials are structurally robust, easily handled, and able to withstand repeated high-strain loading. When considered together, these two factors are a synergistic pairing, such that a catalyst can be produced efficiently, and components can be produced simply and accurately. The basic understanding of deposition mechanisms and microstructural control, and the development and regulation of nanofibrous growth over length scales covering multiple orders of magnitudes, would not have been possible without this project funding.
